questions.text: A patient in an ENT examination was found to be non-responsive to the smell of coffee, tea and Asafoetida. All of which are pure olfactory stimulants. Which of the following substances will he be able to perceive?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ammonia is not a smell, it is an irritant. This is a case of anosmia. Anosmia is a total loss of the sense of smell.

The sense of smell involves two pathways:

  1. Olfactory pathway (via Cranial Nerve I - olfactory nerve): Stimulated by coffee, tea, asafetida, etc. In this patient, these smells do not elicit a response, → suggests anosmia (olfactory nerve dysfunction).
  2. Trigeminal pathway (via Cranial Nerve V - trigeminal nerve): Stimulated by pungent, irritant substances like ammonia, formalin, menthol, etc. Even in anosmia, the trigeminal nerve can still function normally.
  • The best test for olfaction is the University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test, or UPSIT. It is an olfactory function test designed to assess a person's ability to identify and distinguish different smells.
  • It is often used in clinical settings to diagnose conditions related to the sense of smell, such as anosmia (loss of smell), hyposmia (reduced smell), or to help evaluate olfactory dysfunction in diseases like Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and other neurological disorders.
  • Substances like clove oil, peppermint, and garlic have mixed olfactory and trigeminal stimulation and may not be perceived properly if olfaction is impaired.

choices.text: Lamina papyracea is a part of ethmoid bone.
Inferior Concha is a part of ethmoid Bone
Cribriform plate is a part of ethmoid bone
Middle concha is a part of ethmoid bone

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about ethmoid bone anatomy?
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • The inferior nasal concha is not a part of the ethmoid bone; it is an independent facial bone.
  • The lamina papyracea (Option A ruled out) forms the medial wall of the orbit and is part of the ethmoid bone.
  • The cribriform plate (Option C ruled out) is the horizontal part of the ethmoid bone, forming the nasal cavity roof and transmitting olfactory nerve fibres.
  • The middle nasal concha (Option D ruled out) is a projection from the ethmoid bone’s lateral mass.
  • Additional parts of the ethmoid bone include the uncinate process, lamina papyracea, and cribriform plate.

questions.text: A patient presents with nasal crusting and occasional epistaxis. Anterior rhinoscopy reveals a nasal septal perforation. Which condition is least likely to cause perforation of the cartilaginous nasal septum?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Answer:

  • Tertiary syphilis causes perforation of the bony part of the nasal septum due to gummatous lesions.
  • Tuberculosis, leprosy, and Lupus cause perforation of the cartilaginous part of the septum. (Option A, B & C)
  • Other causes of septal perforation include:
    • Trauma: Most common causes: Nose picking, nasal surgery, septal hematoma, foreign bodies
    • Cocaine snorting, decongestant nasal sprays
    • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis causes perforation of both parts of the septum
  • Treatment:
    • Diagnose and treat the cause
    • Close perforations using septal buttons
    • Keep the nose crust free

Septal Perforation Septal Buttons:

questions.text: A 22-year-old boxer presents to the emergency department after being struck on the face during a match. He complains of bilateral nasal obstruction and has visible swelling over the nasal dorsum. On anterior rhinoscopy, a fluctuant, bluish swelling is seen along the nasal septum on both sides. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The punch to the face has resulted in trauma to the nose and septal hematoma, which should be treated by immediate aspiration or incision and drainage.
  • On examination, a bilateral, soft, fluctuant swelling is noted on both sides of the nasal septum, lifting the mucoperichondrium.

Septal Hematoma:

  • Collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum.
  • Usually bilateral
  • Often results from nasal trauma or septal surgery. The nose is the most prominent part of the face and hence is more prone to injuries.
  • In bleeding disorders, it may occur spontaneously.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Bilateral nasal obstruction (most common).
    • Frontal headache and a sense of pressure over the nasal bridge
  • Treatment:
    • Immediate aspiration or incision and drainage.
    • Followed bybilateral nasal packingto prevent reaccumulation.(Option B ruled out)
    • Systemic antibiotics are used to prevent the formation of a septal abscess.
  • Complications:
    • If not drained, it may organise into fibrous tissue, leading to a permanently thickened septum.
    • Septal abscess is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus
    • Saddle nose deformity

Explanation of other options:

  • Anterior Nasal Packing(Option A):Packing does not address the hematoma and may worsen the pressure or delay proper management.Packing is used for epistaxis, not septal hematoma as a first-line treatment.
  • Start Intravenous steroids(Option C):Steroids have no role in acute septal hematoma.They might reduce inflammation but do not resolve the hematoma or prevent cartilage necrosis.
  • Start Topical corticosteroid nasal spray(Option D):Nasal sprays are used for allergic rhinitis, nasal polyps, etc.They are not useful in structural complications like hematoma and would delay essential surgical management.

choices.text: Inferior turbinate pressing on the nasal septum
Middle turbinate pressing on the nasal septum
Superior turbinate pressing on the nasal septum

questions.text: The etiology of anterior ethmoidal neuralgia is:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Direct contact between the middle turbinate and septum can compress the anterior ethmoidal nerve branches, resulting in neuralgic facial pain .

Anterior Ethmoidal Neuralgia:

  • Also known as anterior ethmoidal nerve syndrome, it is a condition characterised by facial pain or headache, particularly around the medial canthus, root of the nose, and sometimes extending to the forehead.
  • This is due to irritation or entrapment of the anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (from the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, CN V1).
  • Etiology of anterior ethmoidal neuralgia:
  • Nasal anatomical abnormalities:
    • Deviated nasal septum (DNS) causing contact with middle turbinate
    • Concha bullosa (pneumatized middle turbinate)
    • Nasal spur or sharp bony ridges
  • Chronic sinonasal inflammation:
    • Chronic rhinosinusitis leading to mucosal irritation
    • Allergic rhinitis with mucosal hypertrophy
  • Post-traumatic or post-surgical nerve entrapment:
    • Nasal or ethmoid bone trauma
    • Complication of functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS)
  • Sinus tumors or polyps:Rarely, compress or irritate the anterior ethmoidal nerve pathway

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric endocrine clinic by her mother due to concerns about the delayed onset of puberty. On further questioning, the patient reveals that she has had difficulty perceiving smells since childhood. On examination, she has underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

The clinical features of delayed puberty, along with impaired sense of smell, point towards a diagnosis of Kallmann syndrome.

Kallmann Syndrome:

  • Type of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism associated with anosmia or hyposmia due to agenesis or hypoplasia of the olfactory bulbs and arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus.
  • Congenital anosmia is a hallmark feature.
  • Pathophysiology: Failure of migration of GnRH-secreting neurons from the olfactory placode to the hypothalamus → Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism
  • It results in delayed or absent puberty and a lack of secondary sexual characteristics.

Explanation of other options:

  • Turner's Syndrome (Option A): Genetic abnormality of 45, XO (monosomy X). Common features include short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, primary amenorrhea, but a normal sense of smell.
  • Klinefelter's Syndrome (Option B) is caused by the genetic abnormality 47, XXY (male with extra X chromosome), and the patient shows clinical features of tall stature, small firm testes, gynecomastia, infertility, and mild intellectual disability. Occurs in males and Puberty may be delayed, but is not associated with olfactory dysfunction.
  • Down's Syndrome (Option D): It is caused by the genetic abnormality Trisomy 21, and the patient shows clinical features of Intellectual disability, upslanting palpebral fissures, flat facial profile, and simian crease. No association with delayed puberty or anosmia.

questions.text: The given two nasal features are seen in which stage of Syphilis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Saddle nose and nasal perforation are seen in the above images, are characteristic of tertiary syphilis.

Primary Syphilis: (Option B)

  • Manifests as a primary chancre of the vestibule of the nose. It is rare.

Secondary Syphilis: (Option C)

  • Manifests as simple rhinitis with crusting and fissuring in the nasal vestibule, skin rash, fever and generalised lymphadenitis.

Tertiary Syphilis: (Option D)

  • This is the stage in which the nose is commonly involved.
  • Typical manifestation is the formation of agumma on the nasal septum.
  • Perforationof the bony and cartilaginous nasal septum and hard palate.
  • The bridge of the nose collapses, causing asaddle nose deformity.

Congenital Syphilis: (Option A)

  • Early form: First 3 months of life as 'snuffles.'
  • Late form: Usually around puberty as gummatous lesions, corneal opacities, deafness and Hutchinson's teeth.

choices.text: Mulberry appearance of nasal mucosa- --Inferior turbinate hypertrophy
Strawberry appearance of nasal mucosa-tuberculosis of nose

questions.text: Which of the following is a wrong match?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Strawberry appearance of the nasal mucosa is seen in Sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis:

  • Granulomatous disease
  • It is a systemic disorder with involvement of the lungs, lymph nodes, eyes or skin.
  • In thenose, it presents with submucosal nodulesinvolving the septum or the inferior turbinate with nasal obstruction, nasal pain and sometimes epistaxis
  • X-ray chest showsdiffuse pulmonary infiltrate with hilar adenopathy.
  • Serum and urinary calciumlevels areraised.
  • Serum ACE(Angiotensin converting enzyme) levels are raisedin active disease.
  • Biopsy of the lesions helps to establish the diagnosis.
  • Treatment is with systemic steroids. For nasal symptoms,steroidscan be used locally as a nasal spray.

Explanation of other options:

  • Mulberry appearance of nasal mucosa → Inferior turbinate hypertrophy(Option A):'Mulberry' or 'knobbly' mucosal swelling is a classic sign of mulberry hypertrophy of the inferior turbinate, often associated with chronic rhinitis or refluxâ€‘related inflammation .
  • Strawberry appearance of the nasal mucosa → Tuberculosis of the nose(Option B):A 'strawberry' mucosal appearance is associated with rhinosporidiosis (granular, vascular polyps that bleed easily) or seen in granulomatous diseases like Wegener's granulomatosis or sarcoidosis, not typically tuberculosis.
  • Strawberry Gingiva → Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's)(Option C):The 'strawberry gingiva' is a well-known feature of Wegener's granulomatosis (now called granulomatosis with polyangiitis), with reddish, bumpy gingival mucosa.
  • Hutchinson's teeth → Congenital syphilis(Option D):Hutchinson's teeth-notched, pegged incisors-are a classic hallmark of congenital syphilis.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with olfactory nerve dysfunction?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disease affecting dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra.
  • Olfactory dysfunctionmay be the first clinical sign of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and idiopathic Parkinson's disease (PD).
  • In PD, bilateral olfactory deficits occur before the onset of most of the classical neurological signs. Hence, smell testing may be useful.
  • Other neurodegenerative diseases with olfactory dysfunction:
    • Alzheimer's disease
    • Lewy body dementia
    • Multiple system atrophy
